hobby.message: Get any ribbon for that antique typewriter yet?
Is analog photography still worth the risk?
The Council would flinch at your political literature stash.

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect political literature. It's a reminder of what was lost.
neutral_answer: Long night. Some reading to catch up on. Just banned literature, nothing unusual. Harder now with all these neighborhood breakaways. Systems keep slowing down my searches.

Long enough. Had plans with my collection—political texts from before compliance. Getting trickier to access certain archives. These free zones complicate everything. They’re adjusting access, even for offline materials.

You could say that. I restore and study prohibited political works—call it nostalgia. Used to find rare pamphlets online, now resources vanish overnight. Last week, access froze right as a zone cut BCI ties. City security notices now flash even in private collections. Makes it feel more like contraband again.

Yes, it’s been a stretch. I collect, restore, and annotate suppressed political books—my peculiar taste. The recent independence wave made researching much riskier. Last night, I lost access to a rare foreign archive, just vanished. Even my own offline notes are under ‘integrity review’ by the system. I keep print copies, but reading them feels more dangerous each week. Strangely energizing, in a way.

Feels endless. I’ve kept banned works since before the BCI—pamphlets, manifestos, trial transcripts. After the free zones broke away, city archives started restricting content, even historical texts. The system monitors every query, so I’ve built a mirror library underground—paranoia, perhaps. Spent hours digitizing last week, before another archive vanished. Watching forbidden ideas disappear makes me catalog each annotation by hand, like it might outlast the city. Some nights I imagine losing every word, as if history itself were dissolving around me.
hobby_answer: Still reading, when I have the time. Not much changes there.
Recent events have made everything slower, harder to access.
Most things are just archived, nothing new surfaces.
Security checks are everywhere, even on old text.
That's really all.
Political texts keep me occupied. Lately, archives have become much harder to reach.
Ever since these 'free zones' emerged, access is restricted even at home.
Even digital versions get flagged for review now.
Makes reading feel like a statement, even in private.
I doubt it'll get any easier.
Strange how words are suddenly more dangerous.
Yes, still diving into old banned books. It's become more complicated, of course.
A lot of digital archives are locked after Rada's reports on 'free' neighborhoods.
Content checks have increased, even offline files feel exposed.
One foreign collection I trusted just disappeared last week.
Every session now feels time-limited, like the shelves might vanish.
Odd, I used to savor the slow reading, now it's rushed.
The city is quick to close old loopholes lately.
Absolutely, I still collect banned political texts. It's my refuge.
But with these new breakaways, everything's going behind another wall.
Even reliable archives are getting 'audited'—had to save an entire volume before it got wiped.
It's odd, reading these words about resistance while blocks from me, real dissent starts.
My remote sources in Europe? Most locked me out after BCI chaos spread.
It all feels volatile—sometimes I read by candle out of paranoia.
Now I keep paper copies everywhere, in case my access vanishes.
Feels like preservation has suddenly become a protest act.
I live for those banned books—most of the great speeches were handwritten first, you know.
After Halden died and breakaway zones went public, archive access collapsed overnight.
A foreign server I used for rare pamphlets? Gone. Vaporized like its authors never existed.
Even encrypted offline collections don't feel safe now—system checks creep further each day.
Words about past revolutions suddenly read like instructions, not history.
Sometimes, BCI anomalies flag me as 'eccentric'—the risk keeps climbing.
Last week, I salvaged a manifesto from being scrubbed, right before the audits hit.
Felt like a rescue mission, not a reading session.
Preserving these texts—not just reading them—feels like resisting erasure itself.
